FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
J & N Fertilizer Co., Inc., Malvern Iowa
Contact: Roger Johnson
Phone:  712-624-8624

Facility Policy

J & N Fertilizer Co., Inc. has an active Training program with all employees.  The facility is coordinated with the LEPC and comply with CFR 1910.38.   If an accidental release were to occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Mills County LEPC, and/or any other authorities to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the releas to the community and envirnoment.

Facility Information

J & N Fertilizer Co., Inc., 306 West 6th Street, Malvern Iowa 51551 has a maximum of  270,000 pounds in a storage tank and nurse tanks which are used for the storage for the sale to farmers for direct application as a crop nutrient and anhydrous ammonia is used in blending of fertilizers for retail sale.

Worse Case Scenario and Alternate Release Scenario

The worse case scenario would be of the total contents of a storage tank released as a gas over a period of 10 minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be 78,800 pounds, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85% capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the end point is .92 miles.  The facility has all excess flow devices, Emergency Shut off valves and breakaway valves in place required by the ANSI Standards and State Requirements.  These will help limit exposure in a release situation.

The alternate release scenario, a 3 inch trasfer hose is used as an alternate release scenario followed by release of ammonia for 2 minutes before an automatic excess flow shut-down valve(s) intervenes or remote manual shut-off is closed and stops the flow of ammonia.  The maximum quantity released would be 28,000 pounds.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is .6 miles.  (The most likely potential incident, would be a release from a break in a 1inch transfer hose release scenario followed by release of ammonia for 2 minutes before an automatic excess flow

shut-down valve(s) intervenes or remote manual shut-off is closed and stops the flow of ammonia.  The maxium quantity released would be 3563 pounds.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm is .4 miles.)

Accidental Release Prevention Program

General release prevention is covered in Employee training and all employees are aware of companies emergency action plan.  The facility is in compliance with the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, k-61.1", published by The American National Standard Institute, Inc. (ANSI), and the standards of th U.S.  Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  The ANSI standard has been adopted by reference by Iowa Administrative Code Part 21 - Chapter 43 - Rule43.6(200), "standard for the storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  The OSHA standard is referenced in this RMP Registration Form, see section 8.3(b).

Five Year Accident History

There are continuous changes being implemented where safety is a concern.  Therefore safety improvements are an ongoing process at this facility.  The facility has not had any accidental release in the last five years with offsite exposure.

Emergency Action Plan

Company complies with CFR 1910.38 Emergency Action Plan and is included in County Emergency Response Plan.  A continuous Saftey Program is in place, any updates are added to training agenda and are in implemented company wide.  The company provides state and local authorities with Sara Title III, and Community Right to Know and Emergency Planning  with the required information.
